articles.content:
Mandatory Protocol

Section 52A of the NDPS Act mandates preparation of a detailed inventory of seized narcotic substances and sampling in the presence of a Magistrate. Non-compliance with this mandatory procedure has repeatedly been held to be fatal to the prosecution case.

Courts have granted bail and even acquittal where sampling was done at the spot without Magistrate supervision.

seo.title: Maintenance Rights of Wife under Section 125 CrPC (2026 Guide)
seo.description: 1000+ word legal guide on wife maintenance rights in India, working wife maintenance, amount calculation and enforcement.

articles.content:
Introduction

Maintenance under Indian law is a social welfare mechanism intended to protect a wife from financial abandonment. Section 125 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (now Section 144 BNSS, 2023) ensures that a wife who is unable to maintain herself is provided financial support by her husband.

This provision is not punitive. Courts have consistently held that maintenance exists to preserve dignity and prevent destitution.

What Is Maintenance Under Section 125 CrPC?

Maintenance is a monthly financial allowance ordered by a Magistrate to enable a wife to meet her basic needs. It applies irrespective of religion and personal law, making it one of the most effective remedies available to women in India.

Maintenance is not charity; it is a legal obligation flowing from marriage.

Who Can Claim Maintenance?

The term “wife” includes a legally married wife, a divorced wife who has not remarried, and a wife living separately for valid reasons such as cruelty, neglect, or desertion.

Maintenance may be denied if the wife is living in adultery, has remarried, or refuses to live with the husband without sufficient cause.

Can a Working or Educated Wife Claim Maintenance?

Yes. Indian courts have clarified that education or employment alone does not disqualify a wife from claiming maintenance. The court examines income disparity, standard of living during marriage, and the wife’s ability to sustain herself with dignity.

A wife earning a modest income may still receive maintenance if the husband’s income is substantially higher.

How Is the Amount of Maintenance Decided?

There is no fixed formula. Courts usually grant 20–30% of the husband’s net monthly income. Factors considered include:

  • Husband’s income, assets and lifestyle
  • Wife’s reasonable needs
  • Children’s education and medical expenses
  • Inflation and cost of living

From Which Date Is Maintenance Payable?

Maintenance may be awarded from the date of application or the date of order. The prevailing judicial trend favours granting maintenance from the date of application to discourage deliberate delays.

What If the Husband Hides Income?

Courts mandate disclosure of income affidavits, bank statements and tax returns. If income is concealed, the court may estimate income and draw adverse inference, often resulting in higher maintenance.

Consequences of Non-Payment

If a husband fails to comply with a maintenance order, the court may attach salary, seize property, issue arrest warrant, and order imprisonment up to one month per default.

Supreme Court Guidelines

In Rajnesh vs Neha, the Supreme Court laid down uniform guidelines requiring mandatory income disclosure, avoidance of overlapping orders and timely disposal of maintenance cases.

Conclusion

Section 125 CrPC remains one of the strongest legal protections for wives in India. Courts today balance fairness with firmness, ensuring genuine claims are protected while discouraging misuse.
